article.title: The remarkable outburst of the highly evolved post-period-minimum dwarf nova SSS J122221.7-311525

multiple_choice_question.text: What unusual feature is most prominently displayed in the superoutburst light curve of SSS J122221.7−311525?
choices: A plateau stage with an abrupt decline
A single, smooth decline from maximum brightness
A double-peaked structure with a temporary fading stage
Rapid, erratic fluctuations in brightness throughout the outburst

multiple_choice_question.text: What change in the B-I color index occurs after the rapid fading phase of the superoutburst in SSS J122221.7−311525?
choices: A rapid shift towards bluer colors
A gradual shift towards bluer colors
A rapid shift towards redder colors

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 6, what is the general trend observed in the amplitude of superhumps during stage B of the superoutburst?
choices: The amplitude increases steadily throughout stage B.
The amplitude decreases steadily throughout stage B.
The amplitude remains relatively constant throughout stage B.
The amplitude fluctuates erratically throughout stage B.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the observed quiescent NIR flux of SSS J122221.7−311525 suggest about its donor star?
choices: It is consistent with a normal, near-main sequence donor star.
It suggests the donor star is unusually hot.
It suggests the donor star is very faint, possibly brown-dwarf like.
It indicates the donor star is completely obscured by the accretion disk.
